intro: Bryonia tayuya, commonly known as the Yucatan bryony, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the Yucatán Peninsula in Mexico. It belongs to the family Cucurbitaceae, which includes cucumbers, squash, and gourds. The plant is characterized by its hairy, branching stems and large, heart-shaped leaves. Its fruits are toxic and resemble small, green gourds, containing a milky sap that can cause skin irritation. Bryonia tayuya is often found in dry, open habitats and is adapted to the tropical climate of its native region.
